verses.text: Saul approved of Stephen's execution. On that day a great persecution arose against the church in Jerusalem, and everyone except the apostles was scattered throughout the regions of Judea and Samaria.
verses.comment: This verse opens with Saul's approval, showing his early hostility towards the church—a background crucial for understanding his later conversion. The scattering of believers, except the apostles, continues the theme of apostolic authority and the centrality of apostolic succession.

verses.text: Devout men buried Stephen and made great lamentation over him.
verses.comment: The care given to Stephen’s burial highlights the respect for martyrs and the importance of honoring the faithful, connecting with longstanding tradition for sacred roles and remembrance.

verses.text: But Saul was ravaging the church, entering house after house. He dragged off men and women and put them in prison.
verses.comment: Saul’s relentless persecution demonstrates the challenges faced by the early church and the enduring strength of the faithful, reminiscent of sustenance through trial.

verses.text: Those who were scattered went about preaching the word.
verses.comment: The persecution serves to spread the gospel more widely. Trials often become instruments for God's purpose in expanding His kingdom.

verses.text: Philip went down to the city of Samaria and began proclaiming Christ to them.
verses.comment: Philip, one of the appointed seven, spreads the message to Samaria—fulfilling Jesus' command in Acts 1:8 to carry the gospel beyond Jerusalem.

verses.text: The crowds were united in paying attention to what Philip spoke, hearing and seeing the signs he performed.
verses.comment: Signs and wonders serve as confirmation of the authenticity of the apostolic message, pointing to divine authority at work.

verses.text: Unclean spirits came out of many who were possessed, crying out with a loud voice. Many who were paralyzed or lame were healed.
verses.comment: Physical and spiritual healings validate the gospel and show the completion of Jesus' work through His followers—an ongoing ministry of healing and liberation.

verses.text: So there was much joy in that city.
verses.comment: The joy resulting from Philip's ministry echoes the joy of the gospel—the kingdom brings fulfillment and peace to those who receive it.

verses.text: But a certain man named Simon, who previously practiced magic in the city and amazed the people of Samaria, claimed to be someone great.
verses.comment: Simon is introduced as a figure representing false miracles and self-exaltation—a contrast to genuine apostolic authority.

verses.text: All the people, from the least to the greatest, paid attention to him, saying, 'This man is the power of God that is called Great.'
verses.comment: Public acclaim for Simon highlights the danger of attributing divine status to human works, a warning against counterfeit authority.

verses.text: And they paid attention to him because for a long time he had amazed them with his magic.
verses.comment: Simon’s prolonged influence by magical arts emphasizes the longstanding susceptibility to deception before the arrival of the true gospel.

verses.text: But when they believed Philip, as he proclaimed the good news of the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
verses.comment: Reception of the gospel is marked by baptism, reiterating the necessity of sacramental initiation into the faith for all believers.

verses.text: Even Simon himself believed, and after being baptized, he stayed with Philip. Amazed, he saw the miraculous signs and mighty works.
verses.comment: Simon's baptism shows openness, but as later verses reveal, genuine conversion is about heart transformation, not just outward acts.

verses.text: When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them.
verses.comment: Acts of oversight by Peter and John reinforce the principle of unity and leadership through the apostles—a continuing, centralized apostolic witness.

verses.text: They came down and prayed for them so that they might receive the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: The ministry of prayer and laying on of hands shows the means by which the Spirit is given—not automatic, but through apostolic authority and sacramental action.

verses.text: For the Holy Spirit had not yet come on any of them, but they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verses.comment: Reception of the Holy Spirit is distinct from baptism here, underscoring a process involving both water baptism and apostolic confirmation—hinting at a layered sacramental structure.

verses.text: Then they laid their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: The laying on of hands by apostles to confer the Spirit parallels later practices in the Church’s ongoing life of imparting spiritual grace.

verses.text: When Simon saw that the Spirit was given through the laying on of the apostles’ hands, he offered them money,
verses.comment: Simon's attempt to purchase spiritual power demonstrates a misunderstanding—true grace is imparted by God through authorized means, not human bargaining.

verses.text: saying, 'Give me this power also, so that anyone on whom I lay my hands may receive the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: Simon's desire to control the Spirit for his own ends highlights the distinction between authorized ministry and self-appointed leadership.

verses.text: But Peter said to him, 'May your silver perish with you, because you thought you could obtain God’s gift with money!'
verses.comment: Peter’s rebuke clarifies that spiritual gifts cannot be bought; they are given freely by God through those He appoints.

verses.text: You have neither part nor share in this ministry, for your heart is not right before God.
verses.comment: Peter points to the necessity of inward purity alongside outward actions—a spiritual order is maintained by righteous hearts.

verses.text: Repent, therefore, of this wickedness, and pray to the Lord, that if possible the intent of your heart may be forgiven you.
verses.comment: Peter calls for repentance and prayer for forgiveness—highlighting the ongoing necessity of conversion and turning away from sin after baptism.

verses.text: For I see that you are in the gall of bitterness and in the bond of iniquity.
verses.comment: Peter speaks directly to the bondage of sin, reminding the reader that spiritual sickness and the need for healing continue after outward profession of faith.

verses.text: Simon answered, 'Pray for me to the Lord, so that nothing of what you have said may happen to me.'
verses.comment: Simon’s response—requesting intercessory prayer—reflects acknowledgment of the power of authoritative prayer from those in Christ’s ministry.

verses.text: When they had testified and spoken the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, proclaiming the gospel to many villages of the Samaritans.
verses.comment: The apostles' continued evangelical mission affirms their universal scope and role in uniting distant regions into one faith family.

verses.text: Now an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, 'Arise and go south to the road that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza.'
verses.comment: Divine guidance comes through angelic messengers, showing God’s direct involvement in expanding the mission to new regions.

verses.text: So he arose and went. And behold, there was an Ethiopian eunuch, an official of Candace, queen of the Ethiopians, who was in charge of all her treasure. He had come to Jerusalem to worship.
verses.comment: The presence of the Ethiopian official shows the gospel’s outreach across ethnic and national boundaries, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies about all nations worshipping the Lord.

verses.text: He was returning and seated in his chariot, and was reading the prophet Isaiah.
verses.comment: Interest in Isaiah’s prophecy foreshadows the fulfillment of messianic promises in Christ, showing the unity between Old and New Testament revelation.

verses.text: The Spirit said to Philip, 'Go over and join this chariot.'
verses.comment: Philip receives prompting from the Holy Spirit—highlighting active divine guidance in individual conversion and ministry.

verses.text: So Philip ran to him and heard him reading Isaiah the prophet. He asked, 'Do you understand what you are reading?'
verses.comment: Philip’s question reveals the need for proper interpretation of Scripture—established tradition and authorized teaching guard against error.

verses.text: He said, 'How can I, unless someone guides me?' And he invited Philip to sit with him.
verses.comment: Scripture reading requires a guide—upholding the necessity of authoritative interpretation through the Church’s teaching office.

verses.text: Now the passage of Scripture he was reading was this: 'Like a sheep he was led to the slaughter; and like a lamb silent before its shearer, so he did not open his mouth.'
verses.comment: Isaiah 53 is a central prophecy concerning Christ’s suffering and sacrifice—interpreted here directly in light of Jesus’ passion.

verses.text: In his humiliation justice was denied him. Who can describe his generation? For his life is taken away from the earth.
verses.comment: The description of Christ’s suffering and death fulfills the prophecy of the suffering servant, unified in spiritual and literal fulfillment.

verses.text: The eunuch said to Philip, 'I ask you, about whom does the prophet say this? About himself or about someone else?'
verses.comment: The crucial interpretive question points to the necessity of authoritative doctrine in revealing the mysteries of scripture.

verses.text: Then Philip opened his mouth, and starting from this Scripture he preached Jesus to him.
verses.comment: Philip’s authoritative explanation reveals Christ as the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy, and sets the standard: the gospel is best understood through guided tradition.

verses.text: As they traveled along the road, they came to some water. The eunuch said, 'Look, here is water. What prevents me from being baptized?'
verses.comment: Desire for baptism at hearing the true gospel shows the immediate, central importance of sacramental entry into the Church, confirming salvation through both faith and works.

verses.text: And Philip said, 'If you believe with all your heart, you may.' He answered and said, 'I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.'
verses.comment: The confession that Jesus is the Son of God reveals high Christology and affirms personal faith in Christ—the necessary condition for baptism.

verses.text: He ordered the chariot to stop; both Philip and the eunuch went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
verses.comment: Physical immersion for baptism mirrors the early Church’s sacramental practice, marking full initiation into the faith community.

verses.text: When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord carried Philip away, and the eunuch did not see him anymore, but went on his way rejoicing.
verses.comment: Philip’s sudden departure emphasizes the mysterious, sovereign work of the Spirit and the lasting joy that follows true incorporation into Christ.

verses.text: But Philip was found at Azotus, and as he passed through he preached the gospel to all the towns until he came to Caesarea.
verses.comment: Philip’s continued missionary journey models enduring evangelism, connecting regions through the spread of the one apostolic faith.
